video.title: Machine Learning Course for Beginners
video.description:
Learn the theory and practical application of machine learning concepts in this comprehensive course for beginners.

🔗 Learning resources: https://github.com/ayush714/ML001-Project-Sources-Code-and-Learning-Materials
💻 Code: https://github.com/ayush714/ML001-Project-Sources-Code-and-Learning-Materials

✏️ Course developed by Ayush Singh. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/c/neweraa

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Course Introduction
⌨️ (0:04:34) Fundamentals of Machine Learning
⌨️ (0:25:22) Supervised Learning and Unsupervised Learning In Depth
⌨️ (0:35:39) Linear Regression
⌨️ (1:07:06) Logistic Regression
⌨️ (1:24:12) Project: House Price Predictor
⌨️ (1:45:16) Regularization
⌨️ (2:01:12) Support Vector Machines
⌨️ (2:29:55) Project: Stock Price Predictor
⌨️ (3:05:55) Principal Component Analysis
⌨️ (3:29:14) Learning Theory
⌨️ (3:47:38) Decision Trees
⌨️ (4:58:19) Ensemble Learning
⌨️ (5:53:28) Boosting, pt 1
⌨️ (6:11:16) Boosting, pt 2
⌨️ (6:44:10) Stacking Ensemble Learning
⌨️ (7:09:52) Unsupervised Learning, pt 1
⌨️ (7:26:58) Unsupervised Learning, pt 2
⌨️ (7:55:16) K-Means
⌨️ (8:20:21) Hierarchical Clustering
⌨️ (8:50:28) Project: Heart Failure Prediction
⌨️ (9:33:29) Project: Spam/Ham Detector

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Wong Voon jinq
👾 hexploitation
👾 Katia Moran
👾 BlckPhantom
👾 Nick Raker
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster
👾 AppWrite

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Learn TML Online
topLevelComment.text:
Round 4 - Machine Learning AI vs. Logical AI

Logic can do machine learning but machine learning cannot do logic and the mathematical proof for that is by using the complexity-theoretic argument that machine learning is under a certain complexity class and logic is under a bigger complexity class and that would be a mathematical proof that indeed logic can do machine learning and machine learning cannot do logic. - Ohad Asor, Founder & CTO of Tau https://tau.net/our-team/

Watch it: 🚀 https://youtube.com/shorts/0shXLPTGBkI

topLevelComment.author: Learn TML Online
topLevelComment.text:
Round 3 - Machine Learning AI vs. Logical AI

Machine Learning is quantitative in nature while Logic-based AI is both qualitative and quantitative. Even things that look qualitative that are done in machine learning like certain natural language processing tasks are being forced into the qualitative models and that's yet another source of their inaccuracy.  - Ohad Asor, Founder & CTO of Tau https://tau.net/our-team/ #Tau #Tauchain #ai #machinelearning #naturallanguageprocessing #logic #models #qualitative 

Watch it: 🚀 https://youtube.com/shorts/mdAwCzDo93A

topLevelComment.author: Learn TML Online
topLevelComment.text:
Round 2 - Machine Learning AI vs. Logical AI

GPT-3 is about machine learning, which is a kind of artificial intelligence that relies on probability and about trying to guess predictions while Tau is based on a completely different kind of artificial intelligence which is logic. It has got nothing to do with probability, it is about absolute statements in the logic and knowledge representation languages. - Ohad Asor, Founder & CTO of Tau #shorts https://tau.net/our-team/

#Tau #Tauchain #Agoras #knowledge #logical #machinelearning #probability #predictions #logic #statements #ai #artificialintelligence #languages #representation 

Watch it: 🚀 https://youtube.com/shorts/JEmclpCtDRQ

topLevelComment.author: the cube man
topLevelComment.text: Well it appears no one bothered to verify the content before uploading this ... I did not watch the entire video, but looked at the linear and logistic regression part. Firstly, the cost function he wrote for linear regression is wrong, 1/m is multiplied and not added to squared error terms. This is a big difference. Secondly, you do not optimize your cost function until it becomes close to zero, that is not practically possible with real world data, and if you were to do that it would mean your model will have absurdly high variance and would require insane number of polynomial features, not to mention that the model will be useless since it wouldn't generalize to new data at all. Should have verified the content before uploading, I don't mean to hate, just to give constructive criticism. Also the way this is being taught is really not that good and won't help anyone build any intuition about the material. Instead use resources that don't rush and explain things with attention.

topLevelComment.author: Capuccino Pintucciono
topLevelComment.text:
Can someone explain to me why we often add "1/m" in cost functions? I get that it gives us the average of whatever we sum next, but shouldn't it be irrelevant? We don't necessarily want a "low" cost function, we just want to "lower" it, if that makes sense.

As a simple example of what I'm trying to say, let's suppose we have, for the same model, two sets of parameters: θ1 and θ2
let's assume we have 5 data points to train with, and we get:
J(θ1) = 2.34
J(θ2) = 5.34
Thus θ1 is the best set of parameters out of the two.
Now let's use, for the same scenario, a cost function without the average (no 1/m). Because we have 5 data points, we can achieve this by simply multiplying the previous cost functions by 5:
J(θ1) = 11.7
J(θ2) = 26.7
So, great, our cost functions increased, but that's completely irrelevant, because what we really care about is the relative improvement from one set of parameters to the other, i.e., θ1 is still about 2.28x better than θ2

While this course contains a lot of information about machine learning and will surely be beneficial for people who want to learn about the subject, the teacher uses a lot of technical jargons which is totally unknown to BEGINNERS.

I would look past the bad and WRONG pronunciation of BASIC concepts like 'discrete' (yeah, it's diScrete not dicrete), 'derivative' (derivaTive not derivIARive), etc. or the constant triple repetition of things  if he wouldn't mess up BASIC ML/math equations, like,

1) The cost function is defined as (1/2m)*sum(...) NOT (1/m)+sum(...)

replies.author: fassstar
replies.text:
@Antern 

1) As my comment was pointing out your mistake of adding a (1/m) term instead of multiplying by it, what you wrote is irrelevant to my comment.

To be clear, I have no disagreement with using 1/m instead of 1/2m, or not using it at all. But as mentioned already, this was not the error I was pointing out.

2) I see that you corrected your errata to remove the erroneous power 2. Good, though you still need to add a multiplied term that is the partial derivative of the terms inside the parentheses with respect to theta j.

replies.author: Antern
replies.text:
@fassstar Hi Thanks for your comment, let me put my thoughts, Wish YT would be sum latex page. 

1.) first let me clear, The 1/2 does not matter and actually, neither does the m - they're both constants. The optimal value of θ would remain the same in both cases.

The expression for the gradient becomes prettier with the 1/2, because the 2 from the square term cancels out.

The m is useful if you solve this problem with gradient descent. Then your gradient becomes the average of m terms instead of a sum, so its' scale does not change when you add more data points.

The 1/2 is for convenience; it makes the derivative, which is the function actually being optimized, look nicer. The 1/m is more fundamental; it suggests that we are interested in the mean squared error. This allows you to make fair comparisons when changing the sample size, and prevents overflow. 

I accept, it should be 1/2m but I was talking about MSE, but still I would have added that, So Sorry. 

2.) When you take out the Partial derivative of the formula that I have written, it will be :- 

= 1/m Σ i = 1 ^ m * ∂/∂ theta_0 (y^hat - y_{i})
= 1/m Σ i = 1 ^ m * 2(y^hat - y_{i})*∂/∂ theta_0 (y^hat - y_{i}) 
= 2/m *   Σ i = 1 ^ m (y^hat - y_{i}) 

and here is the answer. But I am enjoying the conversation, plz put your thoughts will reply back for sure, best conversation ever I have in been. 
btw, Sorry for any wrong formula, I will definitely ask beau to add a errata comment.

replies.author: fassstar
replies.text:
@Antern 

If you know there are errors in the equations given in the video and have a corrections page, that information should be added to the video and video description as a note (even better, a correction note in the video whenever an error is made ... I've seen other people do it). 

As I said, the pronunciation issues are not critical. Nevertheless, it would be good to fix them.

1) Can you please send me a link where the cost function is defined as,
(1/m) +sum(...)
as you wrote it in the video and not,
(1/2m)*sum(...) or (1/m)*sum(...)?

And if you meant that it could be written as (1/m)*sum(...), yes it can, no argument about that. But as I  didn't say it can't be written as (1/m)*sum(...) but that it can't be written  as (1/m)+sum(...), as you  wrote in  the video, please don't accuse me of saying that (1/m)*sum(...) is wrong and of misguiding others as you did.

The 1/m is there because we are taking an average of the square of the errors (and usually taken as 1/2m because the derivative of the square of the errors gives a factor 2), therefore, it makes no sense to add a 1/m which is added to the sum as part of a cost function as it has nothing to do with the distance between the hypothesis and the data.

2) The partial derivative in respect to x of the cost function as you wrote it,

J = 1/m + sum((h(x)-y)^2)

CANNOT be, 

dJ/dx = 2/m + sum((h(x)-y)^2)

as you wrote it. 

(i) The partial derivative of 1/m in respect to x is 0 and not 2/m. And no, as you wrote it as two desperate terms, the factor 2 from the power 2 doesn't multiply the 1/m term in YOUR cost function.

(ii) The partial derivative of sum((h(x)-y)^2) CANNOT be sum((h(x)-y)^2). It is 2*sum(h(x)-y)*dh(x)/dx

Even if you fix the '+' to a '×' it won't change the fact that the partial derivative of f(x)^2 in respect to x cannot be f(x)^2, but is 2×f(x)×df(x)/dx. So even your errata 1 is wrong, because in it you write that the partial derivative is,

(2/m)*sum((h(x)-y)^2) ("... $\frac{2}{m} *  \sum  \limits _{i = 1} ^{m} (\Theta^{T}x^{i} - y^{i})^{2}$ ...", https://github.com/ayush714/ML001-Project-Sources-Code-and-Learning-Materials/blob/main/ML001%20Other%20Materials/Errata%20In%20ML001%20Course.md)

and not,

(2/m)*sum(h(x)-y)*dh(x)/dx 

as the partial derivative of your cost function (i.e., without the factor 2) should be. You wrongly retain the power 2 and wrongly forget to multiply by the partial derivative of the hypothesis.

replies.author: Priyanshu Bhattacharjee
replies.text:
First of all I started coding at age 10 and I don't regret it. Clearly you are a person who belongs from the ideas of 1900s. No one has the right to restrict us, we all are self taught here and you are talking about Indian Education Ministry, do you even know CBSE has collaborated with Intel & Microsoft to teach AI/ML & Data Science. Oh! Sorry how would u know you have a mindset of 1900s. Our parents aren't forcing we are learning bcz we are passionate. Like you I don't believe in learning by age. Anyone can learn anything at any age. You don't have any rights to judge us. I have taught over 100+ students including professors at universities and also I am 16 y/o. I am passionate about technology that's why I learnt and leveraged up my skills. Because of ur mentality kids are ignored and underestimated. If you can't see our success then close ur eyes don't demotivate any of us and we all are self taught I didn't spent a penny learning AR/VR, Web Development, App Development, Game Development & Quantum Computing. I worked as an AR/VR Developer for a year at a startup. Also in India 14+ years of kids can work at tech industry if you don't have any knowledge of law then learn it before saying it.

Coding & Software Development made my life it didn't ruined and you need not to think of us think about yourself what you will do, we are doing good in our fields.

From now on stop demotivating all the kids you guys don't even know what we all kids are capable of. You might have just stuck on ur school subjects but we are more than that.

We don't waste our time like u guys watching worthless TV Shows we use that time to learn and develop. We know how to manage our time, if you don't know then learn it.
